--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> 
> 
> The good news is that I have evolved ANNs that win 95%
> of the time!  I have checked this carefully and have
> confidence in the result.  The evolution seemed to
> stop at about 95%.  I'm not sure why this is, but it
> may be that more neurons are required.  The 95% result
> was with 40 neurons.  
> 
> Since this proves that the ANN can remember a series
> of patterns and then act correctly using that data, it
> would seem that the six card game could be mastered. 
> My hypothesis is that many more neurons are required. 
> Perhaps one or two hundred are necessary.  OTOH, my
> computational resources and patience probably limit me
> to 50 neurons max.  I wonder if there are any
> theortical results that would apply to this problem?
> 

Hey Mitchell, this is a very nice result.  It does make you wonder why
it needs 40 neurons?  (I assume you mean 40 hidden neurons.)
What is going on that such a small amount of information is being
encoded by so many variables?  I also wonder about the theoretical
aspects...what is the theoretical minimum # of neurons needed?

You may want to try ablating neurons, or cutting them out of the
network one by one, and seeing if it still performs alright.  It may
turn out some of them don't matter.  Note that you can ablate a neuron
either by literally removing it, or by turning it's output into random
noise.  I've heard arguments for doing it both ways.

It also makes you wonder how NEAT would do, since it
complexifies..perhaps it can find a smaller solution?  Maybe you could
upload the code for this smaller game as well.

Anyway, very interesting work!

ken
